function.term: Term commonly found on child welfare records

biogHist.abstract: Bring up is stamped on many files from the Child Welfare Department in Western Australia and it was a clerical stamp used like a calendar - as a reminder for things that needed to be done. Bring up does not mean anything at all about bringing up a child.
biogHist.p: For example, on 21 May 1941 a Child Welfare Department (CWD) Inspector reported that the Matron of the Methodist Children's Home in Victoria Park had left and that it might take some time to find a replacement for her. On reading the report, a Welfare Officer at the CWD asked that the file be brought up on 14 July 1941. A series of bring up requests were given for 29 July, and 28 August. Each bring up stamp had another stamp brought up as requested, with a date stamp. Finally, on 28 August, there was a handwritten note on the file to say that a temporary Matron had been appointed.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Methodist Home for Children: reports and general correspondence (Volume 1 of 2) (1923 - 1942)

descriptiveNote.p: The example used to explain 'bring up' was taken from a file at the State Records Office of Western Australia.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: 'Bring Up', in Find & Connect - Western Australia,
